title: Visa cancellations sow panic for international students, with hundreds fearing deportation
author: Alice Masquelier-Page

facts.content: The bar association for immigration attorneys began receiving inquiries from international students studying in the U.S. about their legal status being terminated in early April.
Hundreds of international students have reported losing their legal status and sought advice.
At least 790 students at more than 120 colleges and universities have had their visas revoked or legal status terminated in recent weeks.
1.1 million international students were in the United States last year, providing essential revenue for tuition-driven colleges.
Many of the students losing their legal status are from India and China.
Four students from two Michigan universities filed a lawsuit against Trump administration officials after their F-1 status was terminated.
A federal judge in New Hampshire granted a temporary restraining order to restore the status of a Ph.D. student at Dartmouth College.
A federal judge in Wisconsin issued a similar order regarding a University of Wisconsin-Madison graduate student.
The system to track enrollment of international students came under the control of Immigration and Customs Enforcement after 9/11.
Approximately 242,000 foreigners in the U.S. are employed through 'optional practical training.'

judgements.content: The speed and scope of the federal government’s efforts to terminate the legal status of international students have stunned colleges across the country.
You don’t need more than a small number to create fear.
These are kids who now, under the Trump administration, realize their position is fragile. They’ve preyed on a very vulnerable population.
That is the most scary part because you don’t know whether you’re going to be the next person.

quotes.content: We thought it was going to be something that was unusual. But it seems now like it’s coming pretty fast and furious.
We don’t know, and that’s the scary part.
quotes.source: Ramis Wadood, attorney with the American Civil Liberties Union
